text: Inside a forgotten rocky valley near the World's Edge Mountains lies the tomb of Karitamen, the Death Scarab himself, and deadly foe to Prince Fatandira and her people. The Liche Lord is conspicuously absent, but has left behind many riches and servants, ripe for the taking...
Being both a pleasure barge and a corsair ship, the Flaming Scimitar is only lightly armed with smaller bronze cannons, instead of the heavier artillery of other pirate ships.
From this lookout, the Magus' magician servants cast the most potent spells to aid his forces in battle.
The Minaret of Tempests is where the Golden Magus and his most powerful acolytes cast their strongest spells, directed at enemy forces.
A place for the Golden Magus' many acolytes to study and display their sorcerous abilities.
Only the Magus' most trusted magical pupils are allowed to enter this part of the ship.

Inside this awe-inspiring golden tower is where the source of the Golden Magus' powers resides. Hidden in it, in a location unknown to anyone but the Magus himself reside the 3 magical urns containing the fabled Royal Djinns, drained of their energies for the Magus' benefit.

...The Magus stood up, stretching like a cat in the morning sun. He would allow\\nhimself a break from the frenetically entertaining world of men for a while, perhaps,\\nand spend a little time as a king instead of a servant....
There are many small towns such as this dotting the large swathes of the Arabyan deserts, with its folk often minding their own business detracted from common worldly affairs.
In Araby, small coastal towns such as this heavily rely on pearl trading aside from the usual fishing that goes on over here.

Makeshift markets are a fairly common sight in the balda. One might feel at home between hagglers trying to sway potential customers over here and the occasional thief pickpocketing a confused bystander over there.
Bustling ports and sea-side bazaars span the length of the coast in this town. Slowly but surely, the town is bound to grow to accustom to handling more traders from lands far and wide!
Welcome to the madinah, friend. You will find all sorts of goods and products here! L-look, silk! Silk from faraway Cathay! Aa-and over here, this is a special product - a genie lamp! You will...

Ships from all four corners of the world sail back and forth from these Arabyan coastal cities. Jewels of the desert abundant in resources gained by bartering with traders from the lands of faraway Cathay, mysterious realms of Nippon, jungles of Lustria, the human principalities of the Empire, and even some Norscan tribes.

The larger Arabyan cities mark the epitome of how advanced Arabyan engineering has become. Graceful artisanship of marble-carving has produced stunning results. Dome and column, adorned with glamorous hints of gold. This is a testament of Arabyan - and why, even human - might!
Prospering betwixt marble-column and golden-dome proud, these Arabyan cities are a work of human ingenuity! Unkbeknowst to many though, you may find the usual Skaven under-city from time to time...

Mighty domed palaces laced together to form structures that no living - nor dead - has ever witnessed before. These are confined within tremendously tall walls, in itself surrounded by the large city. The Sultans call this place home, and woe to any who might trespass against their will!

The Arabyans are a proud people... As such, they have built their greatest cities through sweat and blood! Unmatched in architecture and engineering, this city hosts the most grandiose bazaars and ports to be found in Araby. You might also witness the High Elven embassies and trading posts, something you would rarely find outside Ulthuan.

The nawah'i are called home by newly civilized bedouin tribes. They still have a long way to get accustomed to city culture, but as long as they take care of the livestock most Sultans don't really bat an eye.
In Araby, small coastal towns such as this heavily rely on pearl trading aside from the usual fishing that goes on over here.
Villages such as these deal most of their commerce in farming and hunting. You will, however, find the occasional caravan stop somewhere that allows such villages to one day become bustling cities.
Bustling ports and sea-side bazaars span the length of the coast in this town. Slowly but surely, the town is bound to grow to accustom to handling more traders from lands far and wide!

Whether they're on the Silk Road or not, Arabyans will always find a way to trade and make coin. And soon enough, their cities will slowly fill the old world - and perhaps the new - in marble and stone, if left unopposed!

Ships from all four corners of the world sail back and forth from these Arabyan coastal cities. Jewels of the desert abundant in resources gained by bartering with traders from the lands of faraway Cathay, mysterious realms of Nippon, jungles of Lustria, the human principalities of the Empire, and even some Norscan tribes.
These small forts dot the Arabyan frontier often serving as a base for further conquests with many devloping into urbane and administrative centers.
A larger fort used to garrison Arabyan forces but also encompass markets and meeting points for the tribes living beyond the border.
The desert castle is an imposing fortification which helped rulers control and colonise the lands as urban hubs sprouted and flourish alongisde their indomitable walls.
The memory of the night continues to haunt the Arabyans, however, there are some who crave such power. Inside these chambers sleeps the dark shadow that once devastated this land.
The magicians of Araby are experts in all kinds of arcane arts. Surrounded by powerful magical artifacts, masters of sorcery gather on these islands to unveil the mysteries of the sands.

This Tower serves as a testament of Arabyan might; to those who dared pillage and burn their lands and cities for centuries. As a symbol of benevolence; from those who vowed not to do to their aggressors what was done unto them. And a mark of terror; to any who might dare threaten Araby ever again!

Tactile and elegant, Ivory is held in the highest regard to the denizens of Ka-Sabar. This palace was built in tribute to Kasoun by the master architects of Ka-Sabar, and has become the formal residence of the ruling Sultans ever since.
The one who was the ruler of the southern seas built this mighty fortress. Nafel Muq ruled the oceans like a tyrant, and the Arabyan corsairs continue his path.
A nameless horror lives behind its border. A land that knows no other will than that of its tyrannical gods. Many have passed through it, but no one has been able to return...

The glory of the past rises here, in what was the most beautiful wonder in the world, the Gardens of Bel-Aliad. Its vision is a reflection of what Araby once was, the greatest human civilization in the world.
A small workshop that constructs the ancient Ballista's
This grandiose tomb is the greatest pride of the Arabyans. The first Great Sultan, Mullah Aklan’d, lies here. His legend still lives in the hearts of the inhabitants of this land.

The largest of them all is the Palace of the Grand Sultan. This is famous for its riches and luxuries, with large libraries brimming with ancient and unique books, and with temples decorated with idols of the Djinns, the gods of Araby.
We bring fine goods from faraway lands. Pray, what is it you seek?
Built near nomadic settlements they bring a steady trickle of gold and unusual items.
By bringing the tribes of Araby together we can muster a force the like of which has never been seen.
To earn a Giants trust takes time, food and gold but their results on the battlefield speak for themselves.
Under a swift sunrise, the Dhows set out from the docks on their daily routine of carrying Arabyan sailors amidst the seas and oceans for various purposes, most notably pearl hunting.
Merchants from all walks of life can be found here, all focused on one task - to make the most coin possible, doesn't matter how it's done.
In the largest Arabyan cities, you may find harbours entirely dedicated to shipping and receiving slaves. After all, it is on the backs of slaves that the greatest empires are built!
100 Dinars? 200 Dinars? Do we have a deal? Remember folks, this one is well-built and young in its years! Oh-what's that? SOLD!
The sound of chains and whips sure makes one's day a pleasure to go through. The slave markets are prime for business.
Those sold here may be held to the promise of freedom one day. For the esir are just prisoners at this moment, not all moments to be.
Arabyan troops are famous for their elite equipment and training. In the Kasbah, soldiers prepare for combat, while protecting crossing areas and merchant routes.
Small caserns usually exist to employ the mutawa'een - volunteers dedicated to their faith and Sultan!

A city without its guard is a city left to the pickings of thieves and marauders. Thus, it is the city guard's duty to prevent just that from happening! With the usual execution displays in the public square, to ensure a safe and secure... Society.

The Arabyan Guard - those dedicated to guarding the Sultans and Caliphs - are stationed in designated barracks that lie within the royal palaces for absolute protection. None would dare step within these premises.

The Aswad Scythans are loyal servants of the Tomb Kings and go to great lengths to protect and maintain their masters' crypts, in turn, the masters will not hesitate to defend their faithful subjects.

Patrons talk as they sit around smoking from large ornamental hookahs.
Larger establishments offer mouth-watering delicacies, exotic drinks and a wide assortment of Shisha.
The scent of incense and herbs can be traced to the sorcerer's corner. What are they conjuring inside? You wouldn't wanna know. Trust me!

Some sorcerers manage to impress their sultans well enough to have palaces be built in their name. This eventually just becomes a larger playground for those magicians, which spells even better fortune for the sultan - until something explodes, or a spirit that's not meant to be awoken is.. but those are never mentioned in the records of course.

Based on the ancient and often complex system of centralised governance once used in the Southern Realms. This system brings the land under the direct influence of the rulers, unlike the northern feudal systems.
